titleStmt.title: Sheikh Hasan Harran

monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.

spanGrp.span: It is said that one time, šēx Ḥasan called his elderly mother and said, "Come, let's have some fun with the snake."
It is said, she came and said: "What do we do?" He replied: "Wait! Let's steal her eggs!" It is said that the snake has laid eggs in... it has laid them, and they want to take her eggs.
And it is said that they were watching her and removed her eggs from... from atop the straw.
Then they hid and kept watching her. She was in the water—the snake was in the water.
It is said that they were watching her, and the snake came from there after they had taken her eggs.
It is said that when she returned and saw—oh my!—her eggs were gone, and she began to scream.
He and his mother were watching her, observing how she was doing.
It is said that she began to get agitated, looking around searching for them.
She was searching for the eggs, while they were preparing the milk.
She knew where they were preparing the milk, so she went and approached their milk pots.
She slithered over there, drank from the milk, and spat into it to make it poisonous for the household. That's what the snake did!
She was pulling from the milk pot and spitting into it.
She was pulling from the pot and spitting into it, pulling and poisoning that pot. She poisoned it all.
They were watching her, and he said: "Did you see? Look at what the snake did because we took her eggs!" He said to his mother, "Come, let's return her eggs."
They brought the eggs and returned them to their place.
It is said that when the snake returned, crawling from there, she found that her eggs were back in their place.

It is said that she returned; she’s an animal, after all, and understands. She went back to the milk, entered into the milk, and rolled around in it. Then she went to the house, to the kitchen, where the knife was.
She struck herself with the knife and then went into the milk.
When she spoiled the milk, it turned black so they wouldn’t drink it.
So that the household wouldn't drink it, because she had poisoned it—she had put poison in it—to ensure that the household wouldn't be harmed.
As if she knew that they had taken her eggs, she carried out her act! She spat into the milk, poisoned it—to kill them—to kill them.
And when she saw the eggs again, where they had been returned to their place, her eggs, her little ones.
She then went into the milk, rolling in it, and ran to the kitchen, toward the fire.
She went to the stove, to the knife—where she struck herself with the knife—and then returned and entered the pot.
She left after spoiling the milk, ruining it, so that the household wouldn’t drink from it and get poisoned.
Even the snake regretted its actions.
He said to his mother: "Did you see that? The one who has its young taken from it acts like this, even the animal!"
